channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Suspicion Falls on Russia as ‘Snake’ Cyberattacks Target Ukraine’s Government
item.description: No one can quite pinpoint who is behind a series of cyberattacks that began long before President Viktor F. Yanukovych was forced from office, though some suspicion is falling on Russia.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Libyan Militia Selling Oil, Defying the Government
item.description: The weak transitional government appeared powerless to stop a militia group from selling oil, an indication that the nation may be at risk of coming apart at the seams.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Passport Theft Adds to Mystery of Missing Malaysia Airlines Jet
item.description: At least two passengers used stolen passports to board a Malaysia Airlines jet that disappeared Saturday between Kuala Lumpur and Beijing with 239 people aboard, raising the unsettling possibility of foul play.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Ahmad Jauhari Yahya, the chief executive of Malaysia Airlines, addressed the media as the search for the plane continued.

item.title: Rio’s Race to Future Intersects Slave Past
item.description: With a building spree tearing apart sections of Rio de Janeiro, archaeological finds are giving new insight into its old role as a slave trade center.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Lianne Milton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Slave ships in the 19th century docked at the huge stone wharf on Valongo Street, exposed by archaeologists near Rio’s port.

item.title: Kerry Warns Russia Against Annexation of Crimea
item.description: The secretary of state said that any steps by Russia to annex Crimea would bring diplomatic efforts to resolve the crisis in Ukraine to a halt.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: For Ski Break Without Crowds (or Rebels), an Afghan Town Beckons
item.description: Despite the war that rages on elsewhere in Afghanistan, some intrepid tourists are finding their way to Bamian, a mountainous area formerly known for its ancient Buddhas.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: James Robertson of Britain, at left, and Afghans prepared to go skiing last month in Bamian.

item.title: For Families, Memories Mix With Fading Hope
item.description: By Saturday night, the families of the passengers aboard Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 had few answers about what happened and dwindling hope that they would see their loved ones again.
item.dc:creator: By EMMA G. FITZSIMMONS

item.title: Ukraine’s Fight to Fix Economy Is Also a Fight for Legitimacy
item.description: Pavlo Sheremeta, Ukraine’s new minister of economy, said the new government’s urgent priority was cash in the banks, and the second priority is “safety and security in the streets.”
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: On Wednesday, even after forcing a change in the Ukrainian government, demonstrators continued to camp out in Independence Square in the capital of Kiev.

item.title: Tensions Remain High in Crimea Amid Renewed Effort to Mediate
item.description: Russia and Ukraine signaled a willingness to seek a diplomatic resolution, but Russia raised the possibility of suspending nuclear inspections, citing NATO operations.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS and STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pro-Russia demonstrators attended a rally on Saturday in Donetsk, in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Sovereignty vs. Self-Rule: Crimea Reignites Battle
item.description: The showdown in Ukraine has revived a centuries-old debate over when secession is legitimate. Nations’ views vary greatly, depending on their own alliances and interests.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER
item.media:description: A rally backing Russia on Saturday in Sevastopol, in Crimea.

item.title: Mercy and Social Media Slow the Noose in Iran
item.description: Public hangings still attract hundreds of onlookers, but Iran’s enormous middle class is turning against capital punishment.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Strategies: Beware the Market Whiplash of Geopolitics
item.description: Ukraine’s crisis illustrates the risks of short-term investing in many emerging markets.
item.dc:creator: By JEFF SOMMER
item.media:description: Soldiers on the march near a Ukrainian military base outside Simferopol, Crimea’s capital. Ukraine’s crisis touched off two days of breathtaking moves in world stock markets last week.

item.title: Plane’s Landing Gear Catches Fire After a Landing in Nepal
item.description: Only one minor injury was reported among the 182 passengers and crew members on the Air Indigo flight.
item.dc:creator: By BHADRA SHARMA

item.title: China’s Hard Line: ‘No Room for Compromise’
item.description: Wang Yi took a strong stand Saturday on China’s territorial disputes, saying it will “never accept unreasonable demands from smaller countries.”
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: World Briefing: U.N. Body Criticizes Egyptian Crackdown on Dissent
item.description: A group of 27 countries on the United Nations Human Rights Council expressed concerns on Friday over the Egyptian government’s wide-scale use of violence against opposition protesters, the first reprimand from the international body since a bloody crackdown on dissent in the country began last year.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: South Africa’s Diplomatic Dispute With Rwanda Grows
item.description: South Africa expelled three Rwandan diplomats it linked to a raid on an exiled Rwandan general’s Johannesburg home, and Rwanda has retaliated by asking six South African envoys to leave, officials said Friday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: For First Time, Kremlin Signals It Is Prepared to Annex Crimea
item.description: Leaders of both houses of Russia’s Parliament said that they would support a vote by Crimeans to break away from Ukraine, ignoring sanctions threats and warnings from the U.S. and other countries.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS, DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: Ted Turner Expected to Undergo Emergency Medical Treatment in Argentina
item.description: Ted Turner, the American media magnate, was expected to undergo emergency medical treatment in Buenos Aires, Argentina’s national news agency reported Friday.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN GILBERT

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Seeking to Bridge the Arab-Jewish Divide With Music
item.description: David Broza, an Israeli singer-songwriter, employs a universal language on his regular visits with young people at the Shuafat Refugee Camp in Jerusalem.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: David Broza, an Israeli singer-songwriter, during a visit to the Shuafat Refugee Camp in Jerusalem.

item.title: Malaysia Airlines Loses Contact With Jet Carrying Over 200
item.description: Malaysia Airlines said Saturday morning that it had lost contact five hours earlier with a flight carrying at least 239 people to Beijing from Kuala Lumpur, and had activated a search-and-rescue team.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: The arrival board at Beijing Airport listed the Malaysia Airlines flight that lost contact with air traffic controllers on March 8.

item.title: Russia’s Move Into Ukraine Said to Be Born in Shadows
item.description: The Kremlin’s strategy emerged haphazardly as an emotional President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia acted out of what officials called a deep sense of betrayal and grievance.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin, in Sochi, Russia, on Thursday for the Paralympic Games, was taken aback by Ukraine’s upheaval.

item.title: Disgraced Musician Faces an Angry Japan
item.description: Mamoru Samuragochi, who was hailed as a deaf musical genius, said he knew his deception would be revealed one day.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI
item.media:description: Mamoru Samuragochi at a news conference on Friday, his first public appearance since he was revealed as a fake.

item.title: Saudis Put Terrorist Label on Muslim Brotherhood
item.description: Saudi Arabia’s decree appeared to begin an effort to quell the Muslim Brotherhood, reflecting a divide in the Middle East after the military takeover in Egypt last year.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: After Shots, Pistorius Kept Quiet, Guard Says
item.description: On the fifth day of Oscar Pistorius’s trial on charges of murdering his girlfriend, a security guard testified that the South African track star told him that “everything is fine.”
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Pieter Baba with an interpreter during the murder trial of Oscar Pistorius in Pretoria, South Africa, on Friday.

item.title: Snowden Says He Reported N.S.A. Surveillance Concerns Before Leaks
item.description: Edward J. Snowden said that he initially told officials of his concerns about the National Security Agency’s surveillance operations, but that none “took any action.”
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE
